title: K_vin
author: K_vin
content: Norwegian authorities have prosecuted four men in connection with a large-scale investment scam that allegedly defrauded investors of NOK 963 million ($86.5 million) between March 2015 and November 2018.According to Økokrim, Norway’s economic crime agency, the operation worked by encouraging people to buy “product packages” containing digital assets. However, the only money flowing in came from new investors, making it a classic Ponzi scheme.Prosecutors claim more than NOK 700 million ($62.7 million) was laundered through a Norwegian investment firm before being transferred to accounts in several Asian countries.The four accused are Norwegian men in their 50s, 60s, and 70s. Three are suspected of collecting money from investors, while the fourth is accused of handling the laundering process.Among the accused is Terje Hvidsten, a former art dealer with previous fraud convictions. Another suspect, Dag Hætta Eriksen, also has a criminal record related to fraud and corruption. The remaining two suspects include a 52-year-old from Romerike, who denies any wrongdoing, and a 70-year-old former lawyer accused of laundering funds.The scheme operated under different names, including Crypto888 Club, Octa Partners, and Nano Club. Each rebranding introduced a new cryptocurrency—OctaCoin, NanoCoin, and Ormeus Coin. Please guys let's be careful, crypto scams are getting crazier by the day Read the full story here. https://www.bitdegree.org/crypto/news/87-million-crypto-scam-exposed-norway-charges-four-suspects

comments.author: Lucius
comments.body: Quote$87 Million Crypto Scam Exposed, Norway Charges Four SuspectsDoes this have anything to do with Bitcoin? Most cryptocurrencies are by their nature scam projects that have no goal or purpose, and the sooner people realize this, the sooner they will avoid falling for such cheap tricks. The only thing interesting to me in this story is that it managed to happen in Norway, which is one of the best regulated countries in the world, and that they have only now decided to do something about it.Although perhaps all of this is not so strange, the Nordic countries are clearly not what they once were, or at least that's how it seems to me.

comments.author: Davidvictorson
comments.body: We have to be very careful out there. Crypto scams can occur in any country and any continent of the world. People who carry out these scams are regular people and can be from any age group, any profession (as we can see that one of the accomplices is a lawyer by profession). Further, a person who has a criminal record is likely to commit a crime again especially if it was a fraud or corruption case. Lastly, as much as you should buy only Bitcoin, do not participate in a ponzi scheme even if Bitcoin is what is used in it.

comments.author: Hazink
comments.body: Just imagine the fraud that was committed from 2015 to 2018, which is 7-10 years ago, and the scammers being caught, and this period was the time when I even thought people were so much afraid of crypto, not to talk about people falling victim to such a scam that large amount of money.The good thing is that they have been caught, but the victims are those who I pity because their chance of getting their money back is very low. Now that this type of scam awareness is everywhere, it will be harder for a larger number of people to fall victim; some will, but others can easily detect.

Just because they want try to be "smarter" than other people and earn as much as they can.This is something that will never end. The second issue is the total ignorance in financial markets and what should be seen in a company.The worst part (if the stolen money was not enough) is the link made by media since bitcoin and/or crypto are just scams.

comments.created_time: February 19, 2025, 08:12:59 PMLast edit: February 20, 2025, 04:26:23 AM by headingnorth
comments.body: The reality is these scams are impossible to stop. Scamming was very common even before the existence of the internet and crypto. In the old days the scams were sent to people by traditional snail mail, or someone called you on the phone to try to scam you. Of course the scams back then were not related to crypto at all.When I was a kid in the 1980s I remember receiving some of these ridiculous and very obvious scams in the mail and wondered how anyone could be dumb enough to fall for them. People just have to use their common sense and not fall for them, and educate your friends and family about them. They prey on people's greed and stupidity, which seems to be unlimited.

comments.author: Darker45
comments.body: This is kind of interesting. The perpetrators are old men. Usually, it's the other way around. It's usually old men and women who fall victim to such crimes, perhaps because of their limited understanding of new technologies or failure to catch up with the latest. In this case, however, it's old men who developed a somewhat sophisticated crypto scam. They have platforms. They have coins. They rebrand into new platforms with new coins.
